instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2530: What is 820-2530? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.U5000: What is U5000? This is the System Management Controller(SMC) in macbooks from 2013-2015.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V3_S5_REG: What is PP3V3_S5_REG? PP3V3_S5_REG is a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state. .

threads.title: [SOLVED]Old <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Charger Green then Orange No Power
threads.message:
Hi, 
We have two <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not powering up - no fan spin at any moment, exhibiting:
Green then orange light on charger, then we try to jump start by shorting pin 5 to ground, and the orange light disappears for a few seconds, only green remains. Then orange comes back.
Anyone can help with any clues?
And is there a shortcut to testing if SMC is bad? 
TIA!

threads.title: [SOLVED]Old <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Charger Green then Orange No Power
threads.message:
What voltage is <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>? 12.23v or 12.56? Latter is good SMC, former is usually bad?

What's the resistance between pins 17/18 & 27/28 of <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>?

How does <CHIP>U5000</CHIP>/<CHIP>U5001</CHIP> area look?

When you short <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> to ground, does <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> move? This is a two person measurement job unless you're an octopus.

Will this turn on from a charged battery without magsafe?

threads.title: [SOLVED]Old <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Charger Green then Orange No Power
threads.message:
[I]What voltage is <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>? 12.23v or 12.56? Latter is good SMC, former is usually bad? [/I][B]12.27V[/B]

[I]What's the resistance between pins 17/18 & 27/28 of <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>? [/I] [B]20.5 Ohm and 20.5 Ohm[/B]

[I]How does <CHIP>U5000</CHIP>/<CHIP>U5001</CHIP> area look? [/I][B]Clean, no pry damage, nothings seems burnt, no evidence of liquid damage on the board anywhere.[/B]

[I]When you short <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> to ground, does <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> move? This is a two person measurement job unless you're an octopus. [/I]
[B]On <CHIP>U5001</CHIP> <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> measures 3.42V, when I short it to ground, <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> as measured on TP451 decreases from 0.021V to 0.018V.[/B]
P.S.: I soldered a long battery wire to <CHIP>U5001</CHIP>, stuck a probe in TP451 via, stuck another one in a ground hole (I have extremely fine probes), and touched the long jumper to ground while looking at the DMM screen.

Will this turn on from a charged battery without magsafe? [B]No.[/B]

[B]After connecting the (original 60W) charger today to take the requested measurements, I observed that now green and orange lights are gone on the board I'm working with. I did not perform any repair yesterday. All voltages are present at <CHIP>U6900</CHIP> and <CHIP>U6901</CHIP>. All I did yesterday was to remove and re-solder a resistor near ISL, resistance measurements on ISL, and some voltage readings.
Only peculiar thing with this board is a 0 Ohm resistor connecting the ground pads of the capacitors on <SIGNAL>CHGR_VDDP</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>CHGR_LGATE</SIGNAL>, that seems to have been added as an after-thought but in the factory. This is the one I removed then put back.

Oh and at some point today SMC was getting warm. Not hot. [/B]

threads.title: [SOLVED]Old <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Charger Green then Orange No Power
threads.message: 12.23v on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> rather than 12.56v means the SMC is not communicating with <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>. If the data line between the two is intact, meaning not shorted to ground, then 99% SMC is bad or is not being told to turn on properly. What do you get on <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>? <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> has to be 3.4v for the SMC to turn on and work, but should take a short period of time to rise after <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> stabilizes.

threads.title: [SOLVED]Old <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Charger Green then Orange No Power
threads.message:
When you asked about <CHIP>U5000</CHIP> I checked voltages and <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> was 0.15V on Pin 1 of <CHIP>U5000</CHIP>. Measured more than once. 
I am assuming data line from <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> to SMC is <SIGNAL>SMC_AC_OK</SIGNAL>? If yes, not shorted, voltage drop is 0.497. 
Also green light on charger sometimes comes back.

threads.title: [SOLVED]Old <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Charger Green then Orange No Power
threads.message:
anything between 0.431-0.499 is normal for the SMC data line. the issue here is that the SMC will not start until <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is 3.42v.

So either

1) <RESISTOR>R5000</RESISTOR> is bad/doesn't have <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_SMC</SIGNAL> on pin 1
2) <CHIP>U5000</CHIP> is bad
3) SMC is bad and pulling down <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>
4) <TRANSISTOR>Q5032</TRANSISTOR> is shorting <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> to ground because <SIGNAL>SMC_TPAD_RST</SIGNAL> is present on pin 5
5) <TRANSISTOR>Q5032</TRANSISTOR> is bad and sending <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> to ground. 

My guess is 2 or 3. You said SMC gets warm, so....

threads.title: [SOLVED]Old <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Charger Green then Orange No Power
threads.message:
Ok I did replace <RESISTOR>R5000</RESISTOR> and got green and oranges lights back. Still no fan spin.
I tried swapping the SMC and still no change. I am not sure the donor was any good and I don't stock such an old model. Been trying to find another replacement. Will update ASAP.
Thanks for everything till now. Helped me understand the SMC reset circuit for next time, instead of PLZBROing it.

threads.title: [SOLVED]Old <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Charger Green then Orange No Power
threads.message: PPBUS now at 12.56V? <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> present? Resistance to GND on 3V42 rail?

threads.title: [SOLVED]Old <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Charger Green then Orange No Power
threads.message:
PPBUS = 12.56V @ F7000
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_REG</SIGNAL> = 3.319V @ L7220
3V42 = 0.330 red on ground from Pin 5 of <CHIP>U6901</CHIP>

threads.title: [SOLVED]Old <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Charger Green then Orange No Power
threads.message: I asked for resistance not diode.

threads.title: [SOLVED]Old <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Charger Green then Orange No Power
[SOLVED]Old <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Charger Green then Orange No Power
threads.message: That is too low, MCP is dead, the end.

threads.title: [SOLVED]Old <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Charger Green then Orange No Power
threads.message: Thanks. Will organize a decent burial.

threads.title: [SOLVED]Old <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Charger Green then Orange No Power
threads.message: Can you tell me "why" 5.2 K is too low? Can something else be pulling it down that I need to rule out first next time I see this?

threads.title: [SOLVED]Old <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Charger Green then Orange No Power
threads.message: Could be something else, but from experience it is always the MCP. Anything on the 3V42 bus could be causing it, but in most cases I found it to be the MCP. Normal resistance is over 20K.

threads.title: [SOLVED]Old <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Charger Green then Orange No Power
threads.message:
Thank you. 
Before testing for resistance, I have to make sure SMC is working properly or this is separate? 
Could I have from the beginning tested this rail for resistance and not bothered with fixing the SMC?

threads.title: [SOLVED]Old <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Charger Green then Orange No Power
[SOLVED]Old <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Charger Green then Orange No Power
threads.message: Ok thank you, always a pleasure learning from you guys.

threads.title: [SOLVED]Old <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Charger Green then Orange No Power
threads.message:
Just as a last update. Those guys had sent me a donor board together with the board that needed fixing.
i ended up fixing the donor board so to was somewhat a success.
